Award.AwardTitle: Organo-f element Chemistry: Integrated Synthetic, Mechanistic, and Catalytic and Thermochemical Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Tobin Marks of Northwestern University to discover, understand, and optimize chemical transformations involving metal catalysts. Such processes are of central importance to the chemical enterprise and include efficient, atom-economical, and sustainable catalytic processes for producing fuels, plastics, pharmaceuticals, and other economically important chemicals. This project involves four interlinked focus areas that integrate research and education, and deal with fundamental and technologically-oriented aspects of new catalytic reactions utilizing earth-abundant metal catalysts. Computational analysis is being used to understand the catalytic transformations, and most importantly, to discover new ones. A parallel goal being accomplished is the elucidation of principals for new, efficient, useful, atom-efficient, and environmentally "green" catalytic processes. Participation in this multifaceted/multidisciplinary project, including interactions with industrial scientists, is preparing students with diverse backgrounds for careers in industry, government laboratories, and academia.

Professor Marks is studying four research areas: 1) Catalytic hydroelementation to discover, characterize, and understand atom-efficient processes that mediate heteroelement-hydrogen additions to carbon-carbon saturation. This project is focusing on unexplored, lanthanide-catalyzed processes that couple multiple catalytic bond-forming events (cascades), that utilize unsaturated heterocycles (dearomatization), that invent new ways to form oxygen-carbon and sulfur-carbon bonds, and provide actinide catalysts which mediate new bond-forming sequences. 2) Electrophilic catalysis in polar media to study hydroelementation and its reverse using recyclable, highly electrophilic lanthanide catalysts in non-volatile, recyclable ionic liquids or other polar solvents to effect new hydroelementation processes and to develop catalytic reactions that, when coupled to hydrogenation, achieve the microscopic reverse: cleaving carbon-oxygen, carbon-nitrogen, and carbon-sulfur bonds with hydrogen. This research has implications for more efficient processing of sustainable biofuels and other natural resources. 3) Catalytic materials synthesis to use lanthanide, actinide, and related transition metal catalysts in investigating the coupling of olefin polymerization processes with hydroelementation, to produce heteroatom-functionalized polymers, thereby introducing polar functionality at polymer chain ends. 4) Multinuclear catalysis to alter the course of catalytic polymerization and copolymerization reactions by poising two catalytic centers in close proximity. Ideally, such cooperativity effects are likely to alter both the rates and selectivities of kinetic events that control polymer architecture, mechanical properties, and processing characteristics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project joined four closely interlinked focus areas to integrate research and education, and to study fundamentally and technologically-oriented aspects of new and unusual catalytic reactions, primarily utilizing low cost earth-abundant metals. The primary objective which was achieved was to use experimental bond energy information and high-level computation to understand unusual bonding modes, to understand known useful catalytic transformations, and most importantly, to predict new ones. We sought to elucidate principals needed to invent new, efficient, useful, atom-efficient, and environmentally "green" catalytic processes which ultimately enhance the quality of human life. In conducting this research, students engaged in the synthesis and purification of new catalysts, characterizing their molecular structures and dynamics, implementing these catalysts in exploratory reactivity studies, molecular modeling and electronic structure computation, and rigorous elucidation of catalytic reaction mechanism, Students also became familiar with polymer synthesis and with the in-depth polymer characterization--all valuable career skills.

The four research focus areas were: 1) Catalytic Hydroelementation. Here we achieved and expanded the discovery and understanding at a fundamental level, of atom-efficient processes to realize nitrogen-H, oxygen-H, sulfur- H and phosphorous-H additions to carbon-carbon multiple bonds. We developed new earth-catalyzed processes that couple multiple catalytic bond-forming events in cascades, altered the double-bond character of cyclic nitrogen-containing molecules, of interest for pharmaceuticals, invented new ways to form oxygen-carbon and sulfur-carbon bonds that modify bond charged distribution, and investigated rare earth catalysts which catalyzed new bond-forming processes. 2) Highly charged Catalysts. The objectives here, which were achieved, was to use recyclable and highly charged rare earth catalysts in non-volatile, recyclable solvents to demonstrate new catalytic reactions that efficiently cleave carbon-oxygen, carbon-nitrogen, and carbon-sulfur bonds with hydrogen. mastering such transformations has significant implications for more efficient processing of sustainable biofeedstocks and related renewable resources. 3) Catalytic Materials Synthesis. The objective which was achieved was to use rare earth and related transition metal catalysts to introduce polar functionality into plastics for better adhesion and anti-bacterial properties. 4) Multinuclear Catalysis. The objective was to understand how the course of catalytic polymerization and coploymerication reactions can be usefully modified by holding two catalytic centers in close proximity, as in some enzymes. Ideally, these effects will alter both the rates and selectivities of polymerizations to control polymer architecture, mechanical properties, and flow properties for new generations of plastics. These goals were realized with very large catalytic effects. In the process were also discovered how to modify olefin polymerization processes to create highly branched low-mass polyolefins with exceptional friction-reducing properties--a route to new, low-cost machinery lubricants which could significantly reduce US energy consumption. These advances led to an NSF Highlight announcement.

The outcome in this NSF- supported project to discover, understand, optimize and apply catalytic transformations involving metal-carbon and metal-heteroatom containing molecules and fragments is of central importance to the U.S. chemical industry. The transformations of interest in this project are relevant to efficient, atom-economical "green" catalytic processes for the production of fuels, plastics, pharmaceuticals and other economically important chemicals. Significant progress was made. Furthermore, creating a broad chemical knowledge base and also a technically skilled national cadre of researchers trained in this field is crucial to developing ever more selective, environmentally benign, and economically competitive US technologies. There is also a national need for researches trained in basic heavy element chemistry for the US nuclear industry. Such a research/education activity deliberately involves young scientists in all aspects of this knowledge creation. The outcome is that participation in this challenging, multifaceted/ multidisciplinary project, including interactions with industrial scientists, has prepared graduate, undergraduate and postdoctoral students, having diverse backgrounds, for productive careers in industry, government laboratories, and academia.


Last Modified: 10/31/2019
Modified by: Tobin J Marks
